Even some knowledge work benefits from being in person when it's heavily collaborative or involves complex real-time coordination. Emergency response teams, surgical teams, some types of research labs.

The key difference is whether the core function of the job can actually be done remotely without major compromises. For pure knowledge work - writing, coding, analysis, most consulting - remote is clearly better. For work that's inherently physical or requires complex human presence, in-person makes sense.

I think the mistake is trying to force everything into one model. Remote work isn't a universal solution - it's the right solution for work that can actually be done remotely without losing something essential.

The revolution should be about matching work arrangements to what actually makes sense for the work itself, not ideology in either direction.
